front.title: Analysis on 5G System Requirements and GTP-U Specifications

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document analyzes GTP-U specifications and 5GS architectural requirements and shows the result. GTP-U is a user plane protocol standardized in 3GPP and it is used widly in the current mobile networks defined by 3GPP. 5GS is the next generation mobile network system and it is under standardizing in 3GPP.
The resulds would be helpful for clarifying potencial issues on GTP-U in 5G system and it would lead to improve and expand mobile user plane capability.
In addition, it is proceeded to propose several IETF technologies (), and this document provides criteria from the analysis for evaluating GTP-U and such protocols.

section.title: General
section.t:
The 5G system provides date connectivity and services. The functionalities on user plane assumed in are listed below:
Connection of IPv4, IPv6, Ethernet and Unstructured PDU UE mobility Multi-homing for anchor UPFs Flexible UPF selection for PDU Sessions QoS control Policy and charging control Lawful Inspection Identifablity
5G system is potentially defined as a service-based architecture, and PDU sessions are available to be controlled from other authorized network functions via control plane functions.

In addition, 5GS supports network slicing concept. A network slice is a logical network structured of some of network function instances and required resources, and provides special network capabilities and network characteristics. PDU sessions are allocated to the appropriate network slice by AMF depending on their own subscription information. In each network slice, the some of functionality of 5GS user plane are also provided.

section.title: Requirements for Functionalities on User Plane

t.list:
User Plane protocol must support IPv4, IPv6, Ethernet and Unstructured packet to be carried.
<t hangText=UE mobility:"> 5G system must support mobility management of UEs. For optimizing a data path to/from a UE, some forwarding logic depending on the location of a UE might be required. In the current mobile network, a P-GW which is an anchor point terminates GTP-U tunnels from UEs and passes packets from a UE to GTP-U tunnel of another UE. It's possible to cause latency and inefficiencies on traffic forwarding.

section.t: User plane protocol should be multipoint-to-point type tunneling in DL to support the case of multihoming with single PDU session.

t.hangText: Flexible UPF selection for PDU sessions:

section.t: Selecting appropriate UPFs based on some optimize logics could not affect Rel-15 architecture. Putting multiple UPFs in the data path enables to deploy service functions required through the path. It is exptected that multiple UPFs with per session tunnel handling for a PDU session becomes complicated task more and more for a SMF by increasing number of UPFs.

5G system enables UPF to handle multiprex QoS flows in one single PDU session. For QoS control on transport network, QoS class information should be contented in outer IP or Ethernet header(e.g., DSCP and CoS value).

5G system manages policies of PDU sessions depending on their subscription or charging information. In case that multiple andhor UPFs enforce processes to a PDU session, its policy should be shared with such UPFs.
5G should be able to detect and control any PDU session depending on a requiest from external such as government. In some cases, it might be required to provide logs of any PDU session.

In 5G system, each subscriber, user equipment, and network function shall be allocated one identifier such as 5G Subscription Parameter Identifier (SUPI), Parmanent Equipment Identifier (PEI), AMF Name etc. Several control processes on user plane would be executed depending on such indentification infromation, and user plane protocol might be required to convey such information for cases that there are multiple UPFs on a data path of a PDU session.
